{'expiry_datetime': '2026-02-24T13:34:03.924304+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2026-02-24T13:34:03.924304+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_0000000024e461f6a93aa8fbc6b16032', 'size_bytes': 5173518, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 107.78}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 114.36954899900593}
{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Hi, ChatGPT. So, this is Bilal. I'm the co-founder of Bloom, a social enterprise support organization based out of Lebanon. We've been facing a lot of difficulties these years with sanctions and, you know, working in Palestine and Syria. Financially, some of our teams in Palestine are called PALEND, P-A-L-E-N-D. And in Syria, they're called Madad Fund, M-A-D-D-A-D-F-U-N-D. And I've been chatting with them recently, and we've been thinking about how we need to come up with different ways to do crowdfunding and crowdlending, especially as, hopefully, the Syrian situation has changed with the fall of the Assad regime and the sanctions being lifted. And in Palestine, we're in an emergency situation right now, but at the end of the war, there's going to be a lot of resources, inshallah, coming to help with reconstruction and rebuilding. And we would like to prepare the ground to be able to accept funds and distribute funds in an authenticated and trusted way to teams on the ground. And we want to sort of share that. And so, I was thinking about writing a blog as Bloom, describing my conversations with Madad Fund and PALEND. And I was wondering if you could help me organize the blog in a way that could be interesting or help me think about what would be a good direction to take this conversation. I was thinking about including Chris, who is the founder of LaunchGood, who is one of my friends. And since he has a successful crowdfunding platform already, I feel like we have some thing to build upon here. And I'm wondering both what we should do to make this structured, help with the regulations, help with trust, figure out the questions, and also to write a blog describing our journey.", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'Absolutely, Bilal, I’d be happy to help you map this out.

So, it sounds like you’ve got a pretty compelling and timely story to share—especially with the shifting dynamics in Syria and the post-war rebuilding phase in Palestine. Bringing in your experience with Bloom and looping in Chris from LaunchGood gives it a nice, practical backbone.

In terms of structuring the blog, I’d suggest maybe starting with a bit of context. You can paint a picture of the challenges you’ve faced with the old systems—sanctions, financial restrictions, and just the general difficulty of getting funds to where they’re needed. Then you can transition into the recent shifts—like the changes in Syria and the end of the conflict in Palestine—and how that opens a window of opportunity.

After that, you could dive into the conversations you’ve had with the Medad Fund and PalLend teams. Share a little bit about their on-the-ground insights and the specific needs they’ve identified. This personalizes the story and makes it clear that this is about real people and real communities.

And then you can pivot to the solution space. Talk about the idea of innovative crowdfunding and crowd-lending approaches, the importance of trust and regulation, and how you envision building a system that can handle these funds transparently. Including a mention of your connection with LaunchGood and how you’re learning from existing platforms will give readers a sense that this is both collaborative and rooted in proven models.

In the end, you can wrap up with a call to action—maybe inviting readers to follow along as you develop these ideas or to get in touch if they have expertise. That way, you’re not just telling a story—you’re also building a community around the effort.

Let me know if you want me to help draft any specific sections, or if you’d like to dig into any part of that more!', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Yeah, absolutely. So let's get a bit more concrete. For example, there were a few Syrian relief campaigns a couple of years back that tried to use traditional crowdfunding platforms. Some of them ran into issues where the funds got held up by the intermediary banks due to fear of violating international sanctions, even though the campaigns themselves were legal. There was a well-known situation where a European-based NGO had raised a bunch of money for medical aid, but the funds got stuck for months because the banks were nervous about the region. Eventually they had to reroute everything through a partner in a different country, and it just delayed the whole process.\n\nAnother example could be from Gaza. There have been", 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'Yeah, that’s a fair question. So the idea with local partners is that they’re kind of your eyes and ears on the ground. They can navigate the local banking systems and sometimes find pathways that a big international organization might miss. Plus, they can help with the compliance paperwork or the local nuances that make it easier to meet international standards.\n\nNow, you’re right that international sanctions are still a big overarching barrier. Having local partners doesn’t magically make those go away, but it can help you find legitimate, smaller-scale routes or workarounds that comply with the rules. They might know which local banks are more experienced', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'Yeah, absolutely, I get what you’re asking. So the trick with Kiva—or organizations like them—is often that they’re not directly funneling big sums of U.S. dollars straight into a sanctioned country’s banking system. Instead, they work through those local microfinance partners who are already operating with the local currency. So, for example, rather than sending U.S. dollars directly into Syria, they might be working in a currency that’s more locally acceptable or using financial channels that are already established inside the country.\n\nAnd yes, sometimes it’s about working through a partner in a neighboring country or using a different currency that’s not as tightly controlled. It’s definitely not a perfect solution and not everyone can do it, but Kiva’s model is basically to rely on those local organizations that already have a bit of a financial ecosystem in place. So that’s kind of how they get around it, and it’s not always foolproof, but it does help.', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}
